ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

MALAYAN STUDENT UNIT


    1. Mr Lee Kuan Yew asked the Chief Secretary (i) what is the object of the newly-formed Malayan Student Unit in England; (ii) who made the appointment of Mr W. C. S. Corrie as head of the Unit; and (iii) what are his duties.

Column: 1157



    Mr M. P. D. Nair (in the absence of Mr Lee Kuan Yew): Question No. 1.

    Mr J. D. Higham: The answer to the first part of the question is that the Unit is not, as suggested, a new organisation. It was formed in 1953 to take over the responsibilities of the Director of Colonial Scholars in the Colonial Office in respect of students from Malaya.

    As regards the second part of the question, Mr Corrie was appointed by the Governments of Singapore and the Federation of Malaya to take charge of the Unit temporarily, pending a more definitive appointment.

    The duties of the Unit include responsibility for placing students in centres of higher education, the administration of scholarships, arrangements for passages, reception, accommodation and welfare, the administration of the amenities fund, administrative duties in connection with all ranks of the Federation and Singapore military forces and the Royal Malayan Navy attending courses in the United Kingdom.

    Mr M. P. D. Nair: Sir, could the Chief Secretary inform us whether the Government of the Federation of Malaya had consulted the Government of Singapore at the time Mr W. C. S. Corrie was appointed?

    Mr Higham: Yes, Sir.

    Head 5 -

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew (Tanjong Pagar): Mr Chairman, I move,

    To reduce by $2,760 the sum to be allotted in respect of sub-head 3 (2), Principal Assistant Secretary, Grade E, on page 27 of the Estimates.

    Mr Chairman, Sir, the post of Principal Assistant Secretary, Grade E, is a standard one in the service. My information is that the appointment in the Commissioner-General's Office is confined solely to Europeans, and the present holder of the office is a European.

    Sir, may I refer the Government to page 121, sub-head 1 (4) where there is an example of such a post - "Principal Assistant Secretary to Ministry of Commerce and Industry" - which is an upper timescale post?

    I refer the Government also to page 216, sub-head 1 (2) "Principal Assistant Commissioner for Labour, Class II" - an upper timescale post.

    Sir, these officers are taken to the Commissioner-General's Office on transfer from the Singapore Government Establishment and the Malayan Establishment. There is no reason, particularly in view of the desire of the Government to keep all government expenditure, whether on personal emoluments or other unnecessary expenditure, to the

barest minimum, for this post to be upgraded. No explanation has been given why it has been found necessary to make this particular Principal Assistant Secretaryship a superscale appointment when all other Principal Assistant Secretaryships are timescale appointments. If one looks at the number of senior officers in that Division, - one Assistant Commissioner - General for Colonial Affairs, Grade D, one Principal Assistant Secretary, Grade E, one Assistant Secretary, Grade U, one Assistant Secretary, Class II, and two Assistant Secretaries, Class III - we find there are six officers, and of these, three superscale appointments are sought. These are the Assistant Commissioner-General, the Principal Assistant Secretary and the Assistant Secretary, Grade G. Higham): Mr Chairman, Sir, if all the rabbits that the magician from Tanjong Pagar produces out of his hat are as thin as this one, then there will not be even enough meat to make a good rabbit pie. There is no question of an upgrading of these posts. I agree that the tide of Principal Assistant Secretary is used somewhat loosely in the service. It does not necessarily indicate posts of the same grade or importance. There are other Principal Assistant Secretary jobs in the service, including one that is held by a local officer, that carry superscale rank.

    These two particular posts in the Commissioner-General's Office are a backlog

Column: 1160

of Ritsonisation. The Legislative Council approved the Ritsonisation of all superscale posts in Government in 1954. These two posts in the Commissioner-General's Office alone were left out of consideration, because it was necessary for both the Malayan and Borneo Governments concerned to be consulted and their agreement obtained. The Singapore Government's interest in these posts, financially, is only to the extent of 22 per cent. It took some little time to get the Ritsonisation of these two posts agreed. By the time it was done, the Legislative Council had ceased to exist.

    I must admit here that there has been an error in that the sanction of this Assembly to the Ritsonisation of these posts was not sought at an earlier time. Had it been sought, I should have asked you, Mr Chairman, to consider ruling this motion out of order under Standing Order 33 (1) (b) in that it would affect the emoluments already drawn by an existing officer. As it is, I can only say that there is no question of upgrading. In fact, the total pay that would have been paid had these posts been substantively occupied would have been no greater. In certain circumstances, it might even have been less than under the pre-Ritson regime. The posts have, in fact, not been substantively filled because the whole organisation of the Commissioner-General has been in a state of some uncertainty for several years past and it was felt that it would have been improper to appoint substantive officers to these superscale posts - posts that have always been superscale - and then find that they were no longer required in the Commissioner-General's Office.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Mr Chairman, Sir, I am happy to hear from the Chief Secretary that he is very keen to rule out any discussion on the question of pay for European officers by invoking Standing Orders.

    The Chairman: Order. I do not think that is a fair remark.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Mr Chairman, Sir, I was just drawing a reasonable inference from the remark by the Chief

Secretary that he wished this question had received the approval of the previous Legislative Council, in which case he had hoped that no further discussion would be permissible under Standing Order 33 (1) (b).

    The Chairman: Order. We are, as hon. Members know, bound not only by Standing Orders but also by the Order in Council. Standing Order 33 (1) (b), which has been referred to, repeats, in fact, the Order in Council, section 60 (3), and no matter how much hon. Members dislike the Order in Council, we must still consider that we cannot debate any matter which is ultra vires.

    Now Standing Order 33 (1) merely says:

    "Except with the recommendation or consent of the Governor signified thereto, the Assembly shall not proceed - ".

in the relevant paragraph (b) -

    "upon any bill or motion, which, in the opinion of the Speaker or the Attorney-General, would affect any alteration in the salary, allowances or conditions of service... of any public officer..."

That, I think, is the Standing Order to which the Chief Secretary has referred but, in fact, it does not arise in this case. It might arise in other cases, I do not know, but the point is that a motion can be made but it cannot be proceeded with under our constitution without the Governor's recommendation or consent.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: As you will, Mr Chairman, Sir. I am glad the House has been reminded this morning of the limitations under which this Assembly operates.

    Mr Chairman, Sir, the Chief Secretary has explained to us that this was the backlog of the Ritson revision and that, in fact, the amount to which the Singapore Government is committed is only 22 per cent. But he has not explained to us why it has been thought necessary to upgrade the Principal Assistant Secretary to Grade E and the Assistant Secretary to Grade U.

    I understand the Chief Secretary has admitted before the Malayanisation Commission that there is no person in

Column: 1162

Malaya who can do a proper job analysis, to put these various jobs in their proper categories and give them their proper values. Up to now all we have had from the Chief Secretary is an explanation that this was the backlog of a revision which might have been made much earlier and he was sorry that it was not made earlier. But he has not given us any reason why, in the opinion of the Government, they are prepared to support to the extent of 22 per cent this upgrading of two posts.

    Mr Higham: As I have said before, and as I repeat now, there has been no upgrading.

    Question on the amendment put, and negatived.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Mr Chairman, Sir, I move,

    To reduce by $3,120 the sum to be allotted in respect of sub-head 3 (3), Assistant Secretary, Grade G, on page 27 of the Estimates.

    There is very little I wish to add at the moment to what has been said with respect to the Principal Assistant Secretary. The Chief Secretary denies that there has been an upgrading, but I think he cannot deny that in the Remarks column those scales have been shown as being pushed up.

    Question proposed.

    Mr Higham: I would only comment on the last remark of the hon. and learned Member for Tanjong Pagar that the scales may appear to have been pushed up, but the total emoluments proposed have not, in fact, been increased. This is pure Ritsonisation which means consolidation of a proportion of the old cost of living allowance into the basic rates of pay. Lest there should be any further misapprehension, may I remind you, Sir, that this consolidation was, on balance, a greater benefit to the local officer than to the expatriate?

    Head 10 -

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Mr Chairman, I move,

    To reduce by $10,400 the sum to be allotted in respect of sub-head 1 (2), Senior Auditors, on page 39 of the Estimates.

    Mr Chairman, Sir, the increase is because the Government proposes to put up the number of Senior Auditors from one to two. In the Estimates for 1955, on page 34, there was provision for one Senior Auditor and two Auditors. Now it is sought to create two Senior Auditors and two Auditors. Mr Chairman, Sir, if one looks at the 1955 Establishment List, on page 16, one finds these posts, which were allowed in 1954, set out as follows: Upper timescale, one appointment, Senior Auditor; timescale, two appointments, two Auditors, one filled by an expatriate, the other vacant. In other words, there is one Senior Auditor, the appointment being filled by an expatriate; two timescale posts, one filled by an expatriate, the other

Column: 1165

vacant. The scale below that is a Div. II scale, filled by a local man, who is Senior Assistant Auditor.

    Mr Chairman, the Financial Secretary himself sent out a circular recently to all heads of departments in which he set out the view of the Government that there should be an absolute economy in new appointments. The Financial Secretary, in his circular of the 2nd of December, said:

    "Heads of departments are requested to re-examine their draft estimates in order to determine whether Estimates of Revenue cannot safely be increased and Estimates of Expenditure substantially reduced. In this connection it is appreciated that Estimates of Expenditure have been prepared with the need for economy clearly in view and have already been scrutinised in the Treasury. On the other hand, it would be appreciated that the position, as disclosed by the Draft Estimates, gives cause for much concern. The co-operation of heads of departments in an effort to close the gap is most earnestly sought."

    And then, in a special reference to Personal Emoluments, he said:

    "Heads of departments are requested to examine all proposals for new appointments with a view to determining whether they are, in fact, essential for the efficient discharge of the business of Government in 1956, and to withdraw any proposals which do not strictly conform to this requirement. Again the provision entered against any post or category of posts should be examined with great care in order to determine whether the total amount entered will, in fact, be spent..."

    Mr Chairman, Sir, we have here an attempt to boost up the number of Senior Auditors from one to two and to maintain the number of Auditors at two with no proportionate increase in the staff they are supposed to supervise. There is no increase anywhere. It is not shown in these Estimates. The natural result of the creation of one more post of Senior Auditor means that the expatriate holder of the post of Auditor will go up automatically because he is the next person awaiting promotion. Then there will be two vacancies in auditorship which may be filled by local men or may be filled by expatriates.

    It is commonly known in the Civil Service amongst local officers that this is a game of snakes and ladders. One boosts up a post there and pushes an

Column: 1166

expatriate up there. Then one brings in a local officer here. That is Malayanisation.

    There is not the slightest need for creating one more post of Senior Auditor. There is no increase in the work to be done by Senior Auditors, and the only justification advanced by the Financial Secretary is that it will really not cost us very much because the extra money will be made up by external audit, since this man will be going round auditing Harbour Board accounts and all other semi-government accounts.

    The Opposition feels very strongly that this question must be considered not only in the light of the policy of the Chief Minister to reduce all increases in emoluments to the minimum, but also in the light of the sabotage of the policy of Malayanisation to which the Government is committed.

    Question proposed.

    The Financial Secretary (Mr T. M. Hart): Sir, the Audit Department is perhaps one of the most important departments of Government. In so far as it fulfils the same function for the Government as a firm of private accountants fulfils for companies registered under the Companies Act, it is the watchdog of Government expenditure.

    Now, as the expenditure of Government has increased over the years - Members of the Opposition have drawn attention to it - so has the need for the Audit Department to expand. Again, the activities of Government departments have also increased: so have the activities of the City Council, the Harbour Board, and the Singapore Improvement Trust (whose books are also audited by the Department of Audit) increased; and in future, of course, we will have the task of auditing the books of the Central Provident Fund.

    From the increase in Government expenditure alone over the past five years, hon. Members can see to what extent the work of the Audit Department has increased. During that period the books of the various departments have increased in size and number. The

Column: 1167

work of outside audit has increased. The junior staff has been increased, but the senior directing staff has not increased, with the result that now, in the Audit Department, there is not the necessary degree of supervision and control of audit which is required if a job is to be done efficiently. The amount of supervision which must necessarily be given by qualified and experienced officers has been lacking. Senior officers have not been able to give the necessary amount of time to train junior officers, nor have they been able to give time to considering how their methods of audit should be changed or modified or amended in the light of new accounting methods which have been introduced, not only in Government but in those other bodies whose accounts we audit. For example, in the Central Pay Office we have introduced mechanical accounting; similarly in the other bodies.

    Question on the amendment accordingly negatived.

    Sir, the House will recall that, at the time when the Chief Minister was considering how much he could safely take as his own personal emolument, we the People's Action Party exhorted him, in fact, invited him and his Ministers to take a realistic view of the matter and not to play to the gallery, or to fear the ungenerosity of the Opposition.     Sir, before I make any comment on the sum of $10,000, I want to make it clear to the Chief Minister that we do not, in the least, question his integrity on how the $10,000 will be spent. What we do question is this hypocrisy in saying "We do not want to take $5,000. We will only take $3,500 - "

    The Chairman: Order, order. The word "hypocrisy" has been ruled out.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Mr Chairman, Sir, I apologise for the use of that word, but that word stares us in the face so often in the 200 odd pages of the Budget Estimates. I intend to indicate to the Chief Minister that it is much more reasonable to say, "I am drawing a salary of $5,000 a month and I am living up to that standard." To break it up - and I do not blame the Chief Minister and his elected Ministers for this - is to follow the colonial tradition. They have been accustomed to come before this House and, on being asked, "How much is the Chief Secretary being paid?", would reply, "Turn it up and see what it is." To find out whether it is a reasonable and modest sum for a man in his exalted position of life, one has to turn up and find these items spread over many pages - "Expatriation pay"; "upkeep of house"; "upkeep of garden"; "transport expenses"; etc. And our elected Ministers are being made, perhaps unwillingly, perhaps unconsciously, to fit into the scheme of things. Already they are down for a very modest $150 as transport expenses and down for entertainment expenses of one sort or another.

    Sir, when the Prime Minister of Great Britain had difficulty over his own personal emolument, he went before the House and put matters fairly and squarely before it. There was a debate on it; the thing was properly thrashed out - how the Prime Minister of a large Empire conducts himself - rebates were made and concessions given. We have now a matter that should have been raised at the time when the Ministers came forward before this House for their salaries. They should not, after

Column: 1170

having got their salary, decide that it is not enough after all, and then sneak in entertainment expenses ranging from $10,000 to $2,000; and sneak in transport expenses. Sir, the next Budget might well show that some further unforeseen stresses and strains on the modest emoluments of Ministers have made themselves felt, and further additions may well be attempted in this manner. Our criticism is that the Chief Minister did not come forward frankly and fairly and say that he, as Chief Minister, is getting a sum of $3,500 a month, $500 as a Member of the Assembly, tax free, $10,000 a year for entertainment expenses, $150 for his transport, and so on. He should not come to the House for a vote to increase, piecemeal, the number of perquisites of his office.

    Question proposed.

    Mr Lim Choon Mong (Serangoon): Mr Chairman, Sir, I rise to support this amendment, although it has also been put in by me.

    I would like to add just one or two points to what has been said. We do not say that Chief Ministers must not entertain. We do understand that there must be a certain amount of entertainment, but we must always remember that whenever a Budget is presented, especially this Budget when you say that the deficit is real, then there must be some economy. Now, if there are going to be economies, we will have to refer back to previous years to find out how such expenditures came in. Previously I believe the Chief Secretary was carrying on all such work - all the work of the Ministries rolled into one - and we do find that expenditure in that direction was not as much as it is estimated today. Now that it is spread among many Ministries, I think the expenditure for each Minister should not be much more than what was previously.

    Another point that catches our attention is that in the past few months we have witnessed a few functions which cost Government to the tune of $4,000 in one case. Now, if functions of this nature, thrown open, shall we say, to Mr. and Mrs. Singapore, should be conducted

Column: 1171

on such a large scale, we could ask, "Where will it stop?" Inviting 50 people per elected representative was the number asked for by the Chief Minister. He could easily have asked for even more, and then expenditure would probably rise further. I consider it lavish from all points of view and, because of that, we do propose a cut.

    The Chief Minister (Mr D. S. Marshall): If it please you, Sir, I am so happy to see an example so blatant of the intellectual integrity of the P.A.P., as indicated in today's debate. This House, Sir, has not so short a memory that it forgets that on Monday morning the leader of the P.A.P., the hon. and learned Member for Tanjong Pagar, in castigating me for a sterile speech, blamed me for taking seriously the petty objection of petty politicians in respect of the entertainment allowance. What was "the petty objection of petty politicians" is the objection of the P.A.P. today, and that is the position we are at.

    He has, Sir, suggested that this entertainment allowance should be part of our salary. That is, in fact, what was suggested officially, and in fairness to the officials there was no question of their putting it in this fashion. It was the desire of the elected Ministers who wanted no part of the entertainment allowance as part of their salary, because when you have an entertainment allowance as part of your salary - as is the case, Sir, with respect to the President of the City Council there is always a charge that you under-spend and that you profit by that allowance. I did not think it was fair, either to us or to the public, that we should have a fixed entertainment allowance as part of our salary which we could not be certain of spending precisely. I thought it was only fair to this Assembly that this allowance should not only be entirely outside our salary, but that this Assembly, through its Finance Committee, should have the right to examine in detail our expenditure and to challenge it. The Financial Secretary, as the watchdog of our Treasury, Sir, on one occasion did, I think, challenge the $10 for a basket of

Column: 1172

orchids which I sent to the wife of the Prime Minister of Pakistan! He is entitled to do that and I do not complain.
